#Text=Measure a Dog for a Crate
#Text=Crates can be a great tool for house training puppies , giving your dog a safe space , or even help with separation anxiety .
#Text=Your dog 's crate should be a home within a home , not a prison , and finding the right size is an important factor in making it a comfortable space .
#Text=To find the perfect crate for your pup , you just need their height , length , and weight .
#Text=If you have a quickly growing puppy , look for an adjustable crate so that you do n't need to buy a new one every few months .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Taking Your Dog 's Measurements
#Text=Mark your dog 's measurements on a wall .
#Text=You can more clearly see exactly how long and tall your dog is by having them stand against a wall .
#Text=Mark the wall with something temporary like chalk or pencil .
#Text=Then , measure the marks with a measuring tape .
#Text=Bribe your dog to stand still using a treat , if you can .
#Text=Use a measuring tape to find your dog 's length from nose to tail .
#Text=To get the most accurate measurement , have your dog stand on all 4 paws .
#Text=Measure from the tip of the nose to the base of the tail .
#Text=If you include the entire length of your dog 's tail , the crate will be too big .
#Text=If your dog has a very thick , long tail , include some extra length if you want .
#Text=When your dog wags , the tail will hit the crate , so a little extra length will help .
#Text=Find out how tall your dog is sitting down .
#Text=Measure from the floor to the highest point of your dog 's head .
#Text=If your dog has stiff ears that stand up , include them in your measurement .
#Text=Use a soft measuring tape to more easily find your dog 's height while sitting .
#Text=Weigh your dog .
#Text=If you will ever need to carry your dog in the crate , make sure that your dog is under the maximum weight listed for the crate .
#Text=Otherwise , you might damage or even break the crate if you carry your dog inside .
#Text=Alternatively , you can opt to have separate crates for home and travel .
#Text=Finding the Right Crate
#Text=Add to your dog 's length and height .
#Text=The perfect crate will give your dog enough room to stand up , turn around , sit down , and lie on their side .
#Text=To make sure the crate is big enough , add a few inches to both the height and the length :
#Text=For small dog breeds , add to the height and length measurements .
#Text=For large dog breeds , add to the height and length .
#Text=Go for a plastic crate if your dog is easily distracted .
#Text=Plastic crates have less visibility than wire or metal crates .
#Text=This can give some dogs a sense of security , especially when traveling .
#Text=Plastic crates are also easy to clean and provide some insulation in cold climates .
#Text=It 's best to avoid plastic crates if your dog gets stressed when they ca n't see their surroundings , or if you live in a very hot climate .
#Text=Plastic crates are also better for small dogs than metal crates .
#Text=If you have a larger dog , you can make it feel more secure by draping a heavy blanket over 3 sides of the crate .
#Text=Opt for a metal crate for puppies and dogs that like to see their surroundings .
#Text=Metal crates often come with a panel that lets you adjust the size of the inside .
#Text=They are also easy to clean and affordable .
#Text=You may need to find a waterproof liner to help the crate contain any accidents .
#Text=Strong , excited puppies can bend cheap wire crates with their teeth .
#Text=Look for a reinforced steel crate if you are worried about your puppy escaping .
#Text=Line the crate with a cozy blanket or bed to make it more comfortable .
#Text=Use a soft-sided crate for travel .
#Text=Soft-sided crates are lightweight and easy to transport .
#Text=They are also easy to fold down and store .
#Text=A soft-sided crate is best for a small , well-trained dog .
#Text=Soft-sided crates are not very durable and can be difficult to keep clean .
#Text=They 're best to use for travel only .
#Text=This type of crate is also only suitable for a dog that wo n’t chew on the fabric .
#Text=Buy a resizable crate to save money while your puppy is growing .
#Text=A resizable crate can " grow " with your puppy as they get older .
#Text=These crates come with a divider panel that you can use to make the main area of the crate smaller .
#Text=Make sure that the largest size of the crate will be big enough when your dog is fully grown .
#Text=This is most useful for large breeds that grow quickly .
#Text=Some breeds need an bigger size every 3 months .
#Text=Use a crate on the smaller side to house train your puppy .
#Text=Your puppy needs to be able to sit , lie , and turn comfortably in the crate .
#Text=However , do n't get a crate so large that your puppy can soil one side of it and lie on the other side .
#Text=If you are between two sizes , go for the smaller one .
#Text=A too-large puppy crate can derail house training and make it more difficult for you to teach your dog where to potty .
#Text=Adjust if your dog does n't have enough space .
#Text=If you notice that your dog ca n't comfortably lie down on their side with their legs outstretched , it 's time for a bigger crate .
#Text=If you have an adjustable crate , simply size up .
#Text=If not , measure your dog 's length and height and buy a larger crate according to the new measurements .
